Oh, yes. Did he see any point in trying to ensure that he would continue to be able to eat bluefish? Oh, no.

In the 1970-80's in cooperation with covert Canadian and international fishing interests, greed and malfeasance vacuumed the Outer Banks clean. That rape absolutely destroyed the New Newfoundland/Labrador fishing industry. It put fishing populations on "Tags" and depopulated once thriving fishing communities. This fishing activity had sustained itself for 500 years. These outrages quickly brought a proud Province nearly to its knees.

Cod must be 2-4 years old before they can reproduce. It takes years to get a population up and reproducing.

Cod can grow to over 6 feet and 200 lbs, in from 13 to 25 years of life. Getting them to a size just barely able to reproduce once is not an efficient way to manage them. They need to get big, to reproduce a lot, to put on many pounds of flesh. That takes more years, ten or twenty years.

There is no way to do this faster. It took hundreds of years to wreck it, and it will take a decade or two to fix it, if we once actually settle in to try.

We ought not to allow someone to come in and scoop it all, wipe out everything, so we have to start all over again. That would be insane.

Glad you admire Galen Rowell, but perhaps you have not read John Muir's descriptions of climbing - I recommend either "The Mountains of California", My First Summer in the Sierra", or "The Yosemite" for examples of his climbing and hiking.  Stroll he may have, but that was not his only pace.  Climbing a tree in a Sierra storm, "spreadeagled" on the face of a cliff, and more...
Ten miles into the wilderness is hardly a "trudge"! What a way to think about a modest hike into beauty!

I finally reached one significant milestone of aging this summer when for the first time in my life some teenagers sped past me on the road yelling "out of the way old man," LOL. I flipped them the bird and drove on at the speed limit wearing a very self-satisfied smile.

What strikes me about this column is our American preoccupation with doing daring deeds, even well into our 80s. And reaching a certain age and feeling we’re not quite up to what we used to do in younger years, some of us feel this anguish, as if aging is somehow a curse, a taking away of youthful vigor.

In my 20s, my best friend and his wife came to visit my wife and I. He talked of how the two of them trudged 10 miles or more into the Idaho wilderness. Even then, I didn’t get it, suggesting that for my wife and I, finding a beautiful sunny spot on Mount Tamalpais, setting out a blanket with a picnic lunch and just soaking it in was what we enjoyed.

I’d rather explore nature slowly, even if it’s walking along my suburban street at a leisurely pace, soaking in the changing moods of the sky, the infinite variation of clouds which present themselves, neighborhood birds and in spring, the first blooming flowers.

As I drove home today, driving a leisurely 25 mph, the speed limit on the street, an SUV came roaring up behind, impatient to gain that extra thirty seconds before the next stop sign. I knew what he wanted, so when given the opportunity, I just pulled over to the side and let him go. The last I saw of him after a few stop signs was him still ahead, now maybe forty seconds ahead.

As much as I admired Galen Rowell, I feel much better strolling along at the pace of John Muir.

Most people and most politicians do not know what "more progressive taxes" means. Few understand that wealth, income and consumption can be taxed and that all business taxes are passed to the consumer.
For example, every developed country in the world except the U.S. uses a value added tax (VAT) because it is the fairest way to tax different types of business across different taxing jurisdictions. Some Americans think it is a regressive sales tax but it is really just a fair business income tax that allows each business to deduct the VAT taxes paid by other businesses in the chain of production. It does not allow other tax exemptions (credits, deductions, special rates, deferrals and exemptions) and that is why it is fair.
The VAT tax base is large and thus a VAT of just 8% could replace all of the tax revenue from the 15.3% payroll taxes which reduce take-home pay and U.S. jobs.
i think this argument that we should replace all taxes on businesses and corporations with taxes on consumption on the grounds that this would be fairer is simply nifty.

For the past two years, I put the following statement in the comments section of at least one NYTimes article almost daily. Change 2014 to 2016 and it's as timely now as it was two years ago:

With apologies to Cato the Elder, “GOP delenda est.”

Cato stood in the Roman Senate and said this about Carthage every day for 20 years, until it came to pass, and I will say it every day here in the pages of The Times until it comes to pass.

The time to overthrow the Republican obstructionist tyranny that is killing our states and our country is NOW. We cannot wait until the redistricting of 2020 following the next census. The answer now is to work every day in every state to register Democratic voters, even and most especially where the voting laws are being rigged to suppress them, and then to get all Democrats to the polls every election day. Registration should be on-going, NOW.

As our problems are caused by manipulations of voting, so is our solution possible only through voting. The power of GOP gerrymandering is not limitless, and there are enough unregistered or disaffected potential voters in most voting districts to overcome any gerrymandering scheme. In that way, and no other, lies the salvation of the country. This must be the primary mission of the Democratic Party, and of all thinking Americans, male and female, in every state.

Are we listening?
Pleas do that and give us a choice! Run Warren for President in 2016!

Stagnant wages and diminished household income have ravaged the bottom 50% of Americans. It began with Nixon and his lethally divisive Southern Strategy, and the Republican Party captured the hearts and minds of working class and middle class whites and it's been big business running the show ever since. Carter was only a placeholder, a reaction to Nixon's criminality. From 1968 to 1992, a Democrat was in the White House for only four years. Democratic control of Congress kept a lid on things to a point but the demonization of minorities, the poor, unions and the liberal policies that grew the middle class by Reagan & Bush 1 forever changed the political landscape. That's when the new America that values wealth over labor was reborn and continues to flourish today. The middle class would begin to lose economic gains in the early seventies and it has continued ever since. Gilded Age income inequality is booming, the robber barons are back and Republicans have cleverly assigned the blame to the poor, minorities and Democrats for 50 years.

The despond valley Professor describes is one of desperation and rising hopelessness that seems to have evolved into a general feeling that efforts against the unacceptable status quo are useless. The dismal voter turnout in the 2014 election proved that.

The Democratic Party needs to embrace its liberal roots again, put forth leaders with the guts to speak truth to power and invigorate voters to fight for economic justice at the ballot box.

Thank you for raising the important issue of population growth. I am not sure that the indigenous peoples were that different from us though. The expansion of homo sapiens from Africa to other continents tens of thousands of years ago coincides with the extinction of most large land mammals on each on the same continents. I think we have been hell bent on wiping out other forms of life from the get-go. Moderns humans just have the added "benefit" of more powerful technology that quickens this destruction.
What's the point of land with no humans on it?  Well, let's see: clean drinking water, crops, oxygen to breathe,...

It’s been almost 40 years since I read “A Wealth of Nations” so the memory may be a bit faulty but didn’t Adam Smith write about the effects of human overpopulation on natural resources in the late 18th century? And our exploitation of these has only exacerbated with the development of 20th century technology. But then we are only interested in the short term gains rather than how our actions will affect the future of our species and that of everything else on Earth.

The real Ponzi scheme is the continuing expansion of human populations world wide. Just today I read an article which bemoaned the attitude of the younger generation of Japanese, that many of them do not wish to follow the ways of the older generation, choosing instead to not become married and many not having children.

The columnist was aghast at this trend, as he exclaimed that Japan is still one of the world's biggest economies. He argued that this could be a blow to the global economy if Japan's population falters and falls.

Ironically, there may be some truth to this, but at some point, with many resources becoming scarcer, like fish in the oceans and fresh water even in our country, there will be a pressure to stabilize human populations as we overuse and outstrip resources.

The earth was not made for man alone. Native indigenous people understood this, seeing other animals and living things as a part of the whole and man as simply a part of that whole. When will our arrogant and supposedly advanced species see and act upon this wisdom, known long ago by the earlier peoples who preceded us?

In the 20s/30s eras of extreme inequality there was a countervailing politics and culture. Socialism was very much alive, even in the U.S., with a Marxist critique of the capitalist narrative. FDR welcomed and fought the hatred of the oligarchs with a social democratic program. Writers like John Steinbeck brought the stories of the poor to a mass audience.
Even in the times of the founding of the American republic Tom Paine was advocating a progressive income tax to pay for public pensions and health care and unemployment insurance and universal free public education: the entire structure of the welfare state outlined in The Rights of Man. Poor old Tom Paine, having so condemned British aristocracy he was sentenced to death by the Brits, is rolling over in his grave from witnessing the rise of an American plutocracy far worse than aristocracy.
In the U.S., all impetus for explicit redistribution is lost in the neofeudalist triumphalism, the American "left" so spooked by anti-tax idiocy and Grover Norquist pledges they can't say "raise taxes." Unlike the dirty 30s, the 100 million U.S. underclass and the 15 million poor are disappeared from political discourse and public consciousness.
Where is a Tom Paine to electrify the left with a new series of Common Sense tracts to restore American social solidarity. And where are the unions and a Martin Luther King to proclaim solidarity of the poor?
